text: So moving on to the next slide, a really brief overview of this project is D20 is a Discord bot that allows communities to play governance games in an AI large language model mediated environment.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So groups of people can come together to embark on a governance, what we call governance quests, and experience a diversity of governance structures, decision making processes, power distributions, and cultural dynamics.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: through building the discord bot d20 aims to help lay the collective decision-making foundations necessary for online communities to conduct their own governance experiments do governance education do future scenario planning and make real-life decisions while bonding communities through play and a sense of playfulness i'll pass it to janita
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: Yeah.

text: I wanted to reference.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: OK, so the original inspiration for this project was a tool called Community Rule, which this GIF on the screen depicts.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: Community Rule is basically a templating tool that allows you to define a modular structure for your community's governance.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: So there are four types of modules that you may select and combine culture modules, decision modules, process modules and structure modules.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: And community rule basically allows you to combine and create sort of nested hierarchies of these modules that you can then export into a template format.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: So our original vision was to basically take this, allow someone to export this template and then import it into our Discord bot and have it just work for sort of your community's governance.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: But we also at the same time wanted to kind of have this like notion of gameplay or allow people to experiment with these modules in a very low stakes manner that you could then
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: you know, move forward and take into higher stakes situations like actually using these modules to govern your community.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: So the idea of low stakes is kind of where the governance game idea came from.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: So we started out, you know, developing a more fully fledged kind of game experience and we were trying to
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: design a narrative that took people through a series of different decisions that they had to make as a community.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: And we're trying to be pretty honest to the original structure of community role with respect to these four different types of modules.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: But something we realized as we went along was that game design and making a really kind of interesting and exciting gameplay experience is a hard problem in and of itself.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: And we were kind of trying to accomplish a lot of things at once, we realized.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: So we decided to pare back the game structure a bit and sort of focus it around what we call these mini quests or governance experiences.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: where people in the community can still experiment, but on a shorter timeframe and with less narrative overhead, they can still experiment with these governance modules.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: So we'll get a bit more specific about the actual structure of the game later on, but that was kind of the origin story of the D20 bot.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: One other thing I'll mention is that as we were developing this and
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: doing play tests with different communities.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: We got a lot of feedback around the sort of this LLM mediated communication feature.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: So one of our original ideas was to implement the idea of culture models, but in a more wacky manner by using LLMs to modulate how people are communicating.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: So, you know, for example, we have like an eloquence con types in the discord is translated into Shakespearean English.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: And we found that like people were finding a lot of delight in these culture modules.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: And so we started thinking more about, you know, how this game can allow people to experiment with communication and LLM mediated information landscape or like,
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: how even the frustration that you experience when trying to communicate amongst sort of this like chaos of information can be interesting or can teach us something about governance.

text: It's worth saying that too, because one of the things that kind of was also part of the impetus for this work was some of the past user research that we had done with communities who were interested in incorporating more governance tooling into their suite of online tools.
speaker: SPEAKER_05

text: Val and I in particular did a lot of user research with community participants and leaders while we were doing some work on both MediGov's Gateway project and also Policykit and now Collective Voice projects.
speaker: SPEAKER_05

text: And one of the things that came up a lot in those conversations was
speaker: SPEAKER_05

text: the need for some kind of primer or some kind of accessible way to even develop the kind of governance muscles or impulses that an online community would need to
speaker: SPEAKER_05

text: really make use of the tools.
speaker: SPEAKER_05

text: And Community Rule is actually, at least in my opinion, a really great tool for introducing communities to a very simple kind of representation for what governance could look like.
speaker: SPEAKER_05

text: The drag and drop web app and the kind of simplicity of seeing your structure represented, even though
speaker: SPEAKER_05

text: you can actually get these very strange kinds of recursive structures.
speaker: SPEAKER_05

text: Like you could have values inside of a board, inside of values inside of a board, inside of values inside of a board.
speaker: SPEAKER_05

text: infinitely recursing, but it's a really accessible and approachable way of actually seeing what it means to have a structure, to make something that is often implicit.
speaker: SPEAKER_05

text: We heard that there is a lot of this need for making governance more understandable and tangible.
speaker: SPEAKER_05

text: And so that's part of the reason that we were taking community rule as a foundation.
speaker: SPEAKER_05

text: And then we also heard that there was this desire to have something that was more explicitly interactive.
speaker: SPEAKER_05

text: Tooling can sometimes be set up a poll and then let it run and you don't really get any kind of interactive feedback as a result of participating in that process.
speaker: SPEAKER_05

text: It can feel like a lot of online interactions where you do something maybe you see like a react number go up or down but largely speaking you do something and you kind of don't even know if what you did had any impact and
speaker: SPEAKER_05

text: So this idea of kind of creating a way of introducing people to online governance through play seemed to be something that was coming up in our research.

text: um and it works to influence the group's communication norms with what we call um we picked up the term culture models from the community rule where basically we use large language models to modify the content and the input of users messages and temporarily place the users in the artificially constructed cultural communication environment
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And a lot of these cultural modules have pre-generated large language model prompts that the AI used to transform the text input of the user's message on Discord and give an output.

text: If you type something, your language will be mediated and changed by a bot.

speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: Eloquence makes messages more persuasive.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And in our formulation, it kind of turns the message into like a Shakespearean, like poetry kind of way, which is really, really interesting to read out loud in an environment.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

speaker: SPEAKER_02

speaker: SPEAKER_02

speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: If we turn on the Ritual module, it will align your message with the previous message that's being sent.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: If the previous person says, you know, I love tea or something, and you say, I hate tea, it changes to, I like tea, to have this really interesting mediated group consensus that's very constructed.
